       7             : #ifndef mozilla_NotNull_h
       8             : #define mozilla_NotNull_h
       9             : 
      10             : // It's often unclear if a particular pointer, be it raw (T*) or smart
      11             : // (RefPtr<T>, nsCOMPtr<T>, etc.) can be null. This leads to missing null
      12             : // checks (which can cause crashes) and unnecessary null checks (which clutter
      13             : // the code).
      14             : //
      15             : // C++ has a built-in alternative that avoids these problems: references. This
      16             : // module defines another alternative, NotNull, which can be used in cases
      17             : // where references are not suitable.
      18             : //
      19             : // In the comments below we use the word "handle" to cover all varieties of
      20             : // pointers and references.
      21             : //
      22             : // References
      23             : // ----------
      24             : // References are always non-null. (You can do |T& r = *p;| where |p| is null,
      25             : // but that's undefined behaviour. C++ doesn't provide any built-in, ironclad
      26             : // guarantee of non-nullness.)
      27             : //
      28             : // A reference works well when you need a temporary handle to an existing
      29             : // single object, e.g. for passing a handle to a function, or as a local handle
      30             : // within another object. (In Rust parlance, this is a "borrow".)
      31             : //
      32             : // A reference is less appropriate in the following cases.
      33             : //
      34             : // - As a primary handle to an object. E.g. code such as this is possible but
      35             : //   strange: |T& t = *new T(); ...; delete &t;|
      36             : //
      37             : // - As a handle to an array. It's common for |T*| to refer to either a single
      38             : //   |T| or an array of |T|, but |T&| cannot refer to an array of |T| because
      39             : //   you can't index off a reference (at least, not without first converting it
      40             : //   to a pointer).
      41             : //
      42             : // - When the handle identity is meaningful, e.g. if you have a hashtable of
      43             : //   handles, because you have to use |&| on the reference to convert it to a
      44             : //   pointer.
      45             : //
      46             : // - Some people don't like using non-const references as function parameters,
      47             : //   because it is not clear at the call site that the argument might be
      48             : //   modified.
      49             : //
      50             : // - When you need "smart" behaviour. E.g. we lack reference equivalents to
      51             : //   RefPtr and nsCOMPtr.
      52             : //
      53             : // - When interfacing with code that uses pointers a lot, sometimes using a
      54             : //   reference just feels like an odd fit.
      55             : //
      56             : // Furthermore, a reference is impossible in the following cases.
      57             : //
      58             : // - When the handle is rebound to another object. References don't allow this.
      59             : //
      60             : // - When the handle has type |void|. |void&| is not allowed.
      61             : //
      62             : // NotNull is an alternative that can be used in any of the above cases except
      63             : // for the last one, where the handle type is |void|. See below.
      64             : 
      65             : #include "mozilla/Assertions.h"
      66             : 
      67             : namespace mozilla {
      68             : 
      69             : // NotNull can be used to wrap a "base" pointer (raw or smart) to indicate it
      70             : // is not null. Some examples:
      71             : //
      72             : // - NotNull<char*>
      73             : // - NotNull<RefPtr<Event>>
      74             : // - NotNull<nsCOMPtr<Event>>
      75             : //
      76             : // NotNull has the following notable properties.
      77             : //
      78             : // - It has zero space overhead.
      79             : //
      80             : // - It must be initialized explicitly. There is no default initialization.
      81             : //
      82             : // - It auto-converts to the base pointer type.
      83             : //
      84             : // - It does not auto-convert from a base pointer. Implicit conversion from a
      85             : //   less-constrained type (e.g. T*) to a more-constrained type (e.g.
      86             : //   NotNull<T*>) is dangerous. Creation and assignment from a base pointer can
      87             : //   only be done with WrapNotNull(), which makes them impossible to overlook,
      88             : //   both when writing and reading code.
      89             : //
      90             : // - When initialized (or assigned) it is checked, and if it is null we abort.
      91             : //   This guarantees that it cannot be null.
      92             : //
      93             : // - |operator bool()| is deleted. This means you cannot check a NotNull in a
      94             : //   boolean context, which eliminates the possibility of unnecessary null
      95             : //   checks.
      96             : //
      97             : // NotNull currently doesn't work with UniquePtr. See
      98             : // https://github.com/Microsoft/GSL/issues/89 for some discussion.
      99             : //
     100             : template <typename T>
     101         570 : class NotNull
     102             : {
     103             :   template <typename U> friend NotNull<U> WrapNotNull(U aBasePtr);
     104             : 
     105             :   T mBasePtr;
     106             : 
     107             :   // This constructor is only used by WrapNotNull().
     108             :   template <typename U>
     109      135705 :   explicit NotNull(U aBasePtr) : mBasePtr(aBasePtr) {}
     110             : 
     111             : public:
     112             :   // Disallow default construction.
     113             :   NotNull() = delete;
     114             : 
     115             :   // Construct/assign from another NotNull with a compatible base pointer type.
     116             :   template <typename U>
     117         570 :   MOZ_IMPLICIT NotNull(const NotNull<U>& aOther) : mBasePtr(aOther.get()) {}
     118             : 
     119             :   // Default copy/move construction and assignment.
     120           0 :   NotNull(const NotNull<T>&) = default;
     121             :   NotNull<T>& operator=(const NotNull<T>&) = default;
     122          75 :   NotNull(NotNull<T>&&) = default;
     123             :   NotNull<T>& operator=(NotNull<T>&&) = default;
     124             : 
     125             :   // Disallow null checks, which are unnecessary for this type.
     126             :   explicit operator bool() const = delete;
     127             : 
     128             :   // Explicit conversion to a base pointer. Use only to resolve ambiguity or to
     129             :   // get a castable pointer.
     130         495 :   const T& get() const { return mBasePtr; }
     131             : 
     132             :   // Implicit conversion to a base pointer. Preferable to get().
     133             :   operator const T&() const { return get(); }
     134             : 
     135             :   // Dereference operators.
     136             :   const T& operator->() const { return get(); }
     137             :   decltype(*mBasePtr) operator*() const { return *mBasePtr; }
     138             : };
     139             :

     141             : NotNull<T>

     143             : {
     144         150 :   NotNull<T> notNull(aBasePtr);
     145      135705 :   MOZ_RELEASE_ASSERT(aBasePtr);
     146      135705 :   return notNull;
     147             : }
     148             :

     159             : {
     160             :   return aLhs.get() != aRhs.get();
     161             : }
     162             : 
     163             : // Compare a NotNull to a base pointer.
     164             : template <typename T, typename U>
     165             : inline bool
     166             : operator==(const NotNull<T>& aLhs, const U& aRhs)
     167             : {
     168           0 :   return aLhs.get() == aRhs;
     169             : }
     170             : template <typename T, typename U>
     171             : inline bool
     172             : operator!=(const NotNull<T>& aLhs, const U& aRhs)
     173             : {
     174             :   return aLhs.get() != aRhs;
     175             : }
     176             : 
     177             : // Compare a base pointer to a NotNull.
     178             : template <typename T, typename U>
     179             : inline bool
     180             : operator==(const T& aLhs, const NotNull<U>& aRhs)
     181             : {
     182         707 :   return aLhs == aRhs.get();
     183             : }
     184             : template <typename T, typename U>
     185             : inline bool
     186             : operator!=(const T& aLhs, const NotNull<U>& aRhs)
     187             : {
     188             :   return aLhs != aRhs.get();
     189             : }
     190             : 
     191             : // Disallow comparing a NotNull to a nullptr.
     192             : template <typename T>
     193             : bool

     195             : template <typename T>
     196             : bool
     197             : operator!=(const NotNull<T>&, decltype(nullptr)) = delete;
     198             :

     203             : template <typename T>
